family: As has been clear at least since **hh:hvphon:Lloyd:Angan** there are

Not including Inanwatan, though typological affinities have been noted
**hh:hv:deVries:Inanwatan**. Abom [aob] is included in the basis of
lexicostatical similarities in the range 11-14% **hh:el:Tupper:Abom** and the
gender forms of the verb pace the known caveats of lexicostatistics and transfer
in endangered languages. The pronouns resemble the typical Trans New Guinea
pattern and there are some parallels in the gender system to Ok, but this is not
enough to conclude a Trans New Guinea affiliation for the Anim languages.

comment: An SIL-PNG survey (Kassell, MacKenzie and Potter 2005) found the three proposed
languages were distinct from each other, using both lexicostatistical and
intelligibility testing. Average lexical similarity of the three speech
varieties is between 39% and 58%, as measured with a 170-item standard word
list. The accepted threshold for regarding speech varieties as dialects of a
single language is 70% lexical similarity (SIL 1991); these scores are well
below that threshold. Testing of intelligibility found that speakers of each
variety had 13 - 56% comprehension of recorded texts in the other varieties. SIL
guidelines give a recorded text test score of 75% as the lowest acceptable
indicator of comprehension; again these scores are well below that threshold.
The survey team concluded that Andai, Nanubae and Tapei should be considered
three distinct languages.
iso_retirement.name: Arafundi
iso_retirement.remedy: Split into three languages: Andai [afd]; Nanubae [afk]; Tapei [afp]

classification.family: Interesting well-analysed parallels between Haida, Eyak-Athabaskan and Tlingit have surfaced recently **hh:hv:Enrico:Na-Dene** but do not fit sound correspondences with AET **hh:hv:Leer:AET** and is not enough to conclude a genetic relationship. Similarly, the links to Yeniseic **hh:hv:Vajda:Dene-Yeniseian** is not yet mature enough to conclude a genetic relationship **hh:hv:Campbell:Dene-Yeniseian**, **hh:hv:Starostin:Dene-Yeniseian**, **hh:hv:Gerber:Dene-Kusunda**, **hh:hv:Vajda:Dene-Yeniseian-Progress**.

The core is held together by regular sound correspondences in lexical items between subfamily languages, less systematic verbal extensions and noun class systems **hh:hv:Stewart:Potou-Akanic-Bantu**, **hh:hv:Stewart:Three-Grade**, **hh:hv:PozdniakovSegerer:Atlantiques**, **hh:hv:Hyman:Niger-Congo** **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:154-174, 177-179, 180-189, 194-199, 200-213, 213-223, 223-231, 232-234, 353-358. Mande **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:189-192, 353-358, Kordofanian **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:223-231, 232-234, 353-358, Ijoid **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:174-177, 232-234, 353-358, Kru with/without Siamou **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:177-179, 232-234, 353-358 and Dogon (cf. **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:192-193, 232-234, 353-358) have not yet been shown to stand up to these criteria wherefore they are excluded. The Pre or Mbre language in Côte d'Ivoire, known from wordlists only, is Atlantic-Congo but cannot be assigned to a specific branch at this time **hh:w:Blench:Pre**, **hh:vld:Boukari:Pre** **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:180. The Mpra (= Mpre) language in Ghana has cognates with Atlantic-Congo especially Guang **hh:hew:Goody:Guang**, including numerals 2-5, but the bulk of the little vocabulary that is known, is not Atlantic-Congo **hh:w:Blench:Mpra**. On the grounds that the numerals are less likely to be borrowed, and that lexical innovation may produce vocabulary that looks unrelated to anything else, we count Mpra as an Atlantic-Congo language.

borrowings, we cannot find any cognates in vocabulary or morphology.

classification.family: Dibiyaso is often associated with its northern neighbour Bosavi through a small number of matching lexical items. **hh:hvw:Reesink:Aramia**:12 gives a number of lexical lookalikes between Dibiyaso and Kaluli. These contain a few fairly convincing comparisons where Dibiyasu _p_ corresponds to Kaluli _f_. The items in question are common to the entire Bosavi Watershed group (not just Kaluli) but none are found in the Etoro-Bedamini group. This suggests, that we are dealing with loans between Dibiyaso and the Bosavi watershed group. Similarly, Turumsa and Dibiyaso are said to share as much as 19% lexicostatistical similarity **hh:el:Tupper:Turumsa**, but, looking at the items in question and the sociolinguistic situation, a loan scenario is preferable to a genealogical one.

endangerment.comment: Dibiyaso (10735-dby) = Threatened (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

classification.family: Includes Wanyi and Garrwa.

comment: The languages were probably misanalyzed as dialects of a single language
because, as Breen admits "Garrwa and Wanyi are superficially very similar"
(2003: 426). He concludes an extensive comparison of the two languages by saying
"The many correspondences in grammar, especially the pronoun inventories,
confirm the conclusion that these languages are closely related, but at the same
time the substantial differences in grammar suggest that they must be mutually
unintelligible -- closely related languages rather than dialects of a language"
Garrwa and Wanyi have about 50% shared lexicon, either identical words or
confirmed cognates. Nominal morphology is more or less similar but by far the
most significant difference is the verbal system. Wanyi has no evidence of the
clitic system that Garrwa uses to express TAM, and prefers a richer verb
conjugation to express these instead. Belfrage (2003) corroborates these
conclusions of Breen, and while he revises the verb analysis so that the two
languages resemble each other even further, he maintains the assertion that the
languages are distinct.
Perhaps contributing to the confusion is the asymmetrical distribution of the
two: they both occupy areas about the same size, but per Walsh (1981) Garrwa had
"300+" speakers while Wanyi had a questionable "10?". Moreover, Walsh recognizes
the dichotomy and goes so far as to list Garrwa and Wanyi as distinct subgroups
within a larger family. As Breen (2003) explains, the situation is more complex
than it seems on the surface. Garrwa in fact has two or three true
dialects--Western Garrwa and Eastern Garrwa, the latter of which may or may not
be distinguishable from another variety called Kunindirri (2003: 426).
In terms of higher-level organization, Austin mentions that "The two
closely-related languages Garawa and Wanyi are spoken in an area immediately
north of Wagay. In vocabulary and morphology they are very different from all
the languages discussed above, and are classified as members of a distinct
language family by O'Grady et al" (1981: 327). Breen calls this family "Yanyi,"
explaining "I have used the name Yanyi (the word for 'language' in these
languages) for the group for a number of years... and propose this as a name for
the group that makes no implications regarding its status and does not imply
primacy for either language" (2003: 426).
iso_retirement.name: Garawa

endangerment.comment: Garawa (gbc-gbc) = 10 (Extinct)

classification.family: Evidence for Trans New Guinea membership **hh:hv:Dutton:SETNG**:624-631 **hh:hvld:McElhanonVoorhoeve:TNG** or with other neighbouring families **hh:hv:Dutton:SETNG**:624-631 is clearly insufficient, as the lexical links so far proposed are few and show irregular one-consonant correspondences.

(North) Omotic does not show diagnostic Afro-Asiatic features **hh:hv:Hayward:Omotic:2004**, **hh:hv:Bender:Omotic**, **hh:hv:Bender:Omotic:Lexicon**, **hh:hv:Theil:Omotic**, **hh:hv:Bender:Omotic:2010**, **hh:hv:Theil:Omotic:2012**, and is therefore excluded until such features can be shown. The Mao languages (Hozo, Seze, Bambeshi and Ganza) have not yet been shown to be (North or South) Omotic in morphology and/or core vocabulary, though there are some resemblances with North Omotic **hh:hv:Bender:Mao**, **hh:hv:Bender:Gumuz-Koman-Mao-Omotic**, **hh:hv:Bender:Omotic**, **hh:hv:Bender:Omotic:1975**, **hh:hv:Bender:Omotic:2010**. The evidence for the coherence of North and South Omotic (= Ari-Banna) **hh:hv:HaywardTsuge:Omotic**, **hh:hv:Fleming:Omotic-Cushitic:Lamberti**, **hh:hv:Lamberti:Ari-Banna:1961**, **hh:hv:FlemingLewis:Ari-Banna** is not sufficient **hh:hv:Fleming:Lamberti:Second**, **hh:hv:Lamberti:Ari-Banna**, **hh:hv:Zaborski:Afroasiatic:2007**, **hh:hv:Bender:Omotic:2010**, **hh:hv:Theil:Omotic:2012**. The resemablances between Dizoid and Ta-Ne-Omotic languages (especially Bench) are best explained as loans **hh:hv:Theil:Omotic:2012**:373-374.

hh_ethnologue_comment.comment: A number of ancient European and Ancient Near Eastern languages are not listed in E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24. One of them is Hattic (**hh:s:Girbal:Hattischen**, **hh:s:Kassian:Xattskij**).

endangerment.comment: Hattic (xht-xht) = 10 (Extinct).

classification.family: Heibanic is held together by pronouns, lexical cognates, and form-meaning resemblances in the noun class systems, though with a small question mark for Warnang. The alleged noun class form/meaning correspondences to other Kordofanian groups, namely Rashad and Talodi (with Tegem), in **hh:hv:Schadeberg:Kordofanian**, **hh:hv:Schadeberg:Kordofanische** are not convincing as conclusively genetic. As to form, there is much eclectic selection as well as irregular correspondences, and as to meaning, the methodology of finding non-cognate shared class items is highly dubious. Chance resemblance has not been excluded. The lexical evidence for a Kordofanian unity is weak in the extreme **hh:hv:Blench:Kordofanian**. It follows that the arguments presented for a Niger-Congo affiliation are not compelling either **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:223-231, 232-234, 353-358.

family: Hruso-Aka [hru] is clearly not a Miji dialect as held by **hh:hv:Shafer:Hruso**.
The shared lexicon is attributable to loans, and of what remains, there are
insufficient Tibeto-Burman parallels for a Tibeto-Burman affiliation
**hh:hv:Padun:NAssam**, **hh:hvw:BlenchPost:Arunachal**,
**hh:hv:Anderson:West-Kameng**, **hh:v:Anderson:Hruso**.

endangerment.comment: Levai (5657-hru-lev) = Threatened (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available); Hruso (4278-hru) = Threatened (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

family: **hh:hv:Aschmann:Witotoan** clearly demonstrates the internal unity of Boran and

correspondences **hh:s:FaguaSeifart:Ocaina**,
**hh:hv:SeifartEcheverri:Bora-Witotoan** and are therefore premature.

family: With the proportion of lexicon shared with Kaki Ae, the semantic fields,
metalinguistic awareness, relevant sociolinguistic facts favour a borrowing
scenario **hh:s:Clifton:Kaki**:33-34. The so-called sound shifts alluded to by
**hh:v:Franklin:Kaki-Ae** are, in fact, perfectly predictable loan renderings
given the phonemic systems of Eleman (which has no n/l/r-phonemic distinction)
and Kaki Ae (which has no t/k distinction).

endangerment.comment: Kaki Ae (2220-tbd) = Endangered (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

family: The arguments for considering Kenaboi a taboo-jargon are not compelling
**hh:w:Hajek:Kenaboi**, **hh:w:Benjamin:Kenaboi**. Although potential cognates
can be found for a fraction of the Kenaboi forms **hh:w:Benjamin:Kenaboi**, they
are widely scattered and without systematicity. The simplest explanation is then
that Kenaboi is an isolated language and that the similarities to remote
branches of Austronesian and Austroasiatic are chance resemblances.

classification.family: See **hh:hv:Vovin:Altaic** **hh:v:Georg:Paradigmatic-Morphology** for the latest critique of Altaic.

Neither the Kresh group nor Aja have yet been shown to be a bona fide Central Sudanic language **hh:hv:Boyeldieu:CSudanic**. In particular, the pronominal resemblances involving nasals in various constellations **hh:hv:Guldemann:Pronominal-Macro-Sudan**:119-122 **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:268-269 have only a weak probative value **hh:hv:Hammarstrom:Papuan-Pronouns**. The argument by Santandrea that Aja is a Banda-ised Kresh-family language is convincing **hh:hvs:Santandrea:Kresh** and supported by some lexical evidence **hh:hv:Boyeldieu:Central-Sudanic**:411.

Kru lacks sufficient lexical resemblances and noun class resemblances to conclude a relationship with Atlantic-Congo **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:178-179, 232-234, 353-358. Regarding Siamou, as Prost **hh:s:Prost:Seme**:345 noted, apart from obvious loanwords, Siamou is neither Mande nor Gur. Contra **hh:vw:Person:Siamou**, although there are typological matches, Siamou differs from Kru throughout the comparison, and Siamou can thus not be verified as a Kru language **hh:hv:Zogbo:Kru** **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:177-180.

It is clear from the data collected so far **hh:hvs:Baron:Kwomtari** that Guriaso [grx] shares no more lexical cognates with Kwomtari and Biaka than expected at random, and that's not even when borrowing is discounted (Kwomtari neighbours Guriaso). family: Tegem systematically stands out from Narrow Talodi lexically, pronominally, in
the noun class system and alleged sound correspondences are often irregular. The
alleged noun class form/meaning correspondences to other Kordofanian groups,
namely Rashad and Heiban, in **hh:hv:Schadeberg:Kordofanian**,
**hh:hv:Schadeberg:Kordofanische** are not convincing as conclusively genetic; As
to form, there is much eclectic selection as well as irregular correspondences,
and as to meaning, the methodology of finding non-cognate shared class items is
highly dubious. Chance resemblance has not been excluded. The lexical evidence
for a Kordofanian unity is weak in the extreme **hh:hv:Blench:Kordofanian**. It
follows that the arguments presented for a Niger-Congo affiliation are not
compelling either.

classification.family: The best case for an Eastern Sudanic (of Nilo-Saharan) affilition is **hh:hv:Rilly:Meroitique**, but the comparisons where the meaning of the Meroitic word is known independently, are too few to be convincing, and the comparisons where the meaning of the Meroitic word is not known but inferred from the comparisons, are circular (cf. **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:281-282)

hh_ethnologue_comment.comment: Meroitic, an enigmatic poorly attested extinct language of North Sudan, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:ld:Rilly:Meroe**, **hh:ld:Rilly:Meroitique**, **hh:ld:Griffith:Meroitic**, **hh:hv:Rowan:Meroitic**).

endangerment.comment: Meroitic (xmr-xmr) = 10 (Extinct).

comment: The Mimi language as documented by Gaston Decorse in

**hh:hw:Gaudefroy-Demombynes:Oubangui-Chari** is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24. I have never been able to find out where Decorse collected the wordlist and where his informant came from but presumably it was collected somewhere in SE Chad or NE Central African Republic on Decorse's trip in 1902-1904 (**hh:h:Decorse:Congo-Tchad**) and the wordlist shows Arabic and Maban loans (**hh:hv:Starostin:Mimi**), so it was probably also spoken in Wadai. The language has not been sighted for over a century and is therefore likely extinct.

endangerment.comment: Mimi-Gaudefroy (NOCODE_Mimi-Gaudefroy-NOCODE_Mimi-Gaudefroy) = 10 (Extinct).

affiliation, and apart from this, there are only capricious lexical similarities
to other families **hh:hvld:Voorhoeve:CWTNG**:396-398. Internally, Koneraw and
Mombum (aka Komelom) can be seen to be related from the basic vocabulary
correspondences in **hh:hw:Geurtjens:Marindineesche**.

family: The text analysis of Mure by **hh:hvw:deCrequiMontfortRivet:Capakura** is sound,
but the parallels with Chapacuran are limited to a few words, while the rest it
utterly different. Therefore, the near-identical Chapacuran words are likely to
be loans, especially given that the Mure were missioned together with Chapacuran
peoples. No other relation for the Mure data has been suggested or is apparent.

hh_ethnologue_comment.comment: Mure, an extinct Bolivian language of uncertain affiliation attested only with the Pater Noster in **hh:h:Teza:Americane** and a few sporadic mentions (**hh:hv:Hervas:Americanas**:251, **hh:h:Bueno:Obispado-Santa-Cruz**), is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24. It is not to be confused with the more well-known Chapacuran Bolivian language called Moré or Itene [ite] (**hh:g:Angenot-de-Lima:More**). See also: Itene [ite].

endangerment.comment: Mure (NOCODE_Mure-NOCODE_Mure) = 10 (Extinct).

classification.family: No conclusive, methodologically sound basis for assigning Nara to Eastern Sudanic **hh:hv:Bender:ESudanic** or to an alleged full or partial Nilo-Saharan has been presented **hh:hv:Blench:Nilo-Saharan**, **hh:hv:Bender:Nilo-Saharan:2000**, **hh:hv:Boyeldieu:Nilo-Sahariennes** **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:294-309. More recent more narrow parallels are suggestive but not enough to be conclusive **hh:hv:Rilly:Nara**. The parallels adduced by **hh:hv:Dimmendaal:Nilo-Saharan:Stable** have been selected from various modern languages and have an alternative explanation as chance resemblances until shown to be reconstructable in the various microgroups.

endangerment.comment: Nara (nrb-nrb) = 6a (Vigorous).

classification.family: Narrow Talodi (exluding Tegem) is held together by pronouns, lexical cognates, and form-meaning resemblances in the noun class systems. Tegem systematically stands out lexically, pronominally, in the noun class system and alleged sound correspondences are often irregular. The alleged noun class form/meaning correspondences to other Kordofanian groups, namely Rashad and Heibanic, in **hh:hv:Schadeberg:Kordofanian**, **hh:hv:Schadeberg:Kordofanische** are not convincing as conclusively genetic. As to form, there is much eclectic selection as well as irregular correspondences, and as to meaning, the methodology of finding non-cognate shared class items is highly dubious. Chance resemblance has not been excluded. The lexical evidence for a Kordofanian unity is weak in the extreme **hh:hv:Blench:Kordofanian**. It follows that the arguments presented for a Niger-Congo affiliation are not compelling either **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:223-231, 232-234, 353-358.
classification.sub: **hh:hvw:NortonAlaki:Talodi** (interpreting the significance of the innovations differently)

endangerment.comment: Natchez (10858-ncz) = Awakening

family: The Ndu languages do not show cognate gender markers with Sepik while the
pronouns show some amount of resemblance **hh:hv:Foley:Sepik-Ramu**:126-139.
However, with the extant variety of pronoun forms with the Sepik languages, it
is difficult to ascertain beyond-chance relationships. The best resemblance is
with Kwoma but there is detailed refutation of the evidence so far presented
that Ndu is related to Kwoma-Kwanga (or the rest of Sepik)
**hh:g:Aikhenvald:Manambu**. Yerakai shares no significant lexical relations
with any Sepik language **hh:hvw:ConradDye:USepik**:14, except Ndu
**hh:hv:Laycock:Sepik**:23, but these are arguably loans from the adjacent
Iatmul (as of intermarriage) **hh:hvw:ConradDye:USepik**:14
**hh:hv:Aikhenvald:Sepik**.

endangerment.comment: Nihali (4879-nll) = Threatened (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

classification.family: No conclusive, methodologically sound basis for assigning Nilotic to Eastern Sudanic **hh:hv:Bender:ESudanic** or to an alleged full or partial Nilo-Saharan has been presented **hh:hv:Blench:Nilo-Saharan**, **hh:hv:Bender:Nilo-Saharan:2000**, **hh:hv:Boyeldieu:Nilo-Sahariennes** **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:294-309. No conclusive, methodologically sound basis for assigning Nubian to Eastern Sudanic **hh:hv:Bender:ESudanic** or to an alleged full or partial Nilo-Saharan has been presented **hh:hv:Blench:Nilo-Saharan**, **hh:hv:Bender:Nilo-Saharan:2000**, **hh:hv:Boyeldieu:Nilo-Sahariennes** **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:294-309. The parallels adduced by **hh:hv:Dimmendaal:Nilo-Saharan:Stable** have been selected from various modern languages and have an alternative explanation as chance resemblances until shown to be reconstructable in the various microgroups.

No evidence for the Bogia (Monumbo) languages being related to other Torricelli languages was ever presented **hh:hv:Laycock:Torricelli**. The low lexicostatistical figures from Wom [wmo] **hh:hv:GlasgowLoving:Maprik**:8 notwithstanding, inspection of Wom lexicon shows many obvious correspondences with Torricelli languages (I wish to thank Tim Usher and Matthew Dryer for convincing me of this) but the wide range of lexicostatistical similarity between Wom and various Arapeshan and Kombioic languages suggests than many items are borrowed, so do not constitute unequivocal evidence for subgrouping Wom with Kombioic and Arapeshan.

family: Includes Finisterre-Huon **hh:hv:Suter:Finisterre-Huon**, **hh:hv:Suter:Huon**,
Irian Highlands (Dani and Paniai Lakes subgroups) **hh:h:Foley:2000**, Madang
**hh:h:Foley:2000**, **hh:hv:Daniels:Sogeram**, Ok **hh:h:Foley:2000**,
Awyu-Dumut **hh:h:Foley:2000**, Asmat-Kamoro
**hh:hv:Voorhoeve:Asmat-Kamoro-Awyu-Dumut-Ok**, **hh:hvtyp:deVries:Dumut**,
Oksapmin together with Ok **hh:hv:LoughnaneFedden:Oksapmin-Ok**, Binanderean
**hh:hv:Smallhorn:Binanderean-TNG** **hh:hv:Smallhorn:Binanderean**, Eastern
Highlands **hh:hv:Xiao:HAB**, Mek **hh:hvw:Heeschen:Mek:1978**,
**hh:hvld:Heeschen:Mek:1992**, probable members Engan **hh:h:Foley:2000**,
Chimbu **hh:h:Foley:2000**. See also **hh:hv:Pawley:Voorhoeve**:97 and
**hh:hv:Ross:Voorhoeve**:146 **hh:hv:Daniels:Sogeram:2015** for re-subgrouping
of a few languages. The Bikaru-Bragge wordlist in **hh:hvw:ConradLewis:USepik**
presumably represents the Pikaru dialect of Bisorio (an Engan language) despite
the divergence of the two, since the body part terms agree and the elicitation
sessions were monolingual.
Convincing published lexical evidence exist for the relatedness of
Northern-Southern Je in a Je subgroup **hh:hv:Jolkesky:Proto-Je**, Je-Jabuti
**hh:hv:RibeirovanderVoort:Jabuti-Je**, Je-Karaja **hh:g:Ribeiro:Karaja**:268-287,
Je-Rikbaktsa **hh:hv:Boswood:Aripaktsa**, Ofaye **hh:hv:Gudschinsky:Ofaie-Xavante**,
Maxakalian-Je **hh:hv:Davis:Macro-Je:1968**, **hh:hv:Davis:Macro-Je**, Je-Aimore
**hh:hv:Seki:Krenak-Je:2002**. For Kamakanan the lexical parallels adduced by
**hh:hv:Loukotka:Kamakan** remain to be corroborated using Kamakanan proto-forms
**hh:hvw:Silva:Kamaka** **hh:hv:Ramirez:Koropo**. For Puri-Coroado the lexical
parallels adduced by **hh:hvw:Loukotka:Coroado** cannot be taken as proof of a
genealogical relationship **hh:hv:Ramirez:Koropo**. For Kariri, Bororoan and
Chiquitano there is suggestive, but not conclusive grammatical evidence
**hh:g:Ribeiro:Karaja**:265 **hh:hv:Rodrigues:Macro-Je** **hh:v:Ribeiro:Kariri** (also
shared by Carib and Tupi **hh:hv:Rodrigues:Tupi-Karib-Je**) and little in the way
of lexicon. For Fulniô, Guató and Otí there is insufficient evidence whatsoever
**hh:g:Ribeiro:Karaja**:262-287.

family: Chunene of **hh:hvw:Montano:Bolivia:II**:1-11 is similar to Ese Ejja and
therefore Tacanan (p.c. Willem Adelaar 2008 and Marine Vuillermet 2015). Yora is
mutually intelligible with Yaminahua **hh:e:Shepard:Amazonian**:32-42. The
minuscule wordlist in **hh:w:PalauSaiz:Moxos** of Chiriva
**hh:hv:Hervas:Catalogo**:250 is probably Panoan.
Typological arguments are not sufficient to conclude a Leonard Schultze family
with Walioic **hh:hvld:LaycockZGraggen:Sepik-Ramu**. The lexical evidence does
not show any conclusive genetic relationship either, be it inside or outside
Leonard Schultze **hh:hvw:ConradDye:USepik**, or with Duranmin
**hh:hvw:ConradLewis:USepik** (a higher figure (29%) of Papi-Duranmin
lexicostatistical relations quoted by Laycock earlier, is superseded by the
later, below 10%, figures of Conrad and Lewis).

family: Karkar-Yuri is an Eastern Pauwasi language as is evident by inspection of
wordlists (see **hh:hb:Hammarstrom:Least** for a history of this discovery).
Occasional Pauwasi lexical items and pronoun forms show TNG likeness
**hh:hv:WurmMcElhanon:Papuan**:155-156, **hh:hvld:Voorhoeve:CWTNG**:418-419, but
are not sufficient to conclude a relationship.

classification.family: Despite vocabulary cognacy of 5% or so, Pawaia was included in Trans-New-Guinea because of pronoun resemblances to Kuman and on typological  similarities. The typological similarities involve function only **hh:s:Trefry:KumanPawaian**, and thus count for nothing. The pronoun resemblances do not generalize to the Chimbu family **hh:hv:Foley:Papuan**:69-71 and match only an _n_ anyway, so they are better accounted for as accidental similarities than deep relationship.

endangerment.comment: Pawaia (10740-pwa) = Threatened (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

family: The best case for Payaguá relatedness is with Guaycurú and/or Guachi

classification.family: Rashad is held together lexically and pronominally **hh:hvs:Stevenson:Nuba**:46-52. The noun class system cannot be shown conclusively to be original as there as no secure traces of a loss. The alleged noun class form/meaning correspondences to other Kordofanian groups, namely Talodi (with Tegem) and Heibanic, in **hh:hv:Schadeberg:Kordofanian**, **hh:hv:Schadeberg:Kordofanische** are not convincing as conclusively genetic. As to form, there is much eclectic selection as well as irregular correspondences, and as to meaning, the methodology of finding non-cognate shared class items is highly dubious. Chance resemblance has not been excluded. The lexical evidence for a Kordofanian unity is weak in the extreme **hh:hv:Blench:Kordofanian**. It follows that the arguments presented for a Niger-Congo affiliation are not compelling either **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:223-231, 232-234, 353-358.

family: There are interesting parallels to Wintuan and the rest of Plateau Penutian (=
Molala and Klamath-Modoc) **hh:hv:Liedtke:WintuanPenutian**.

The parallels adduced by **hh:hv:Dimmendaal:Nilo-Saharan:Stable** have been selected from various modern languages and have an alternative explanation as chance resemblances until shown to be reconstructable in the various microgroups.

family: The relation of Sentani-Nafri-Tabla (SNT) to Demta is best argued in
**hh:hv:Cowan:Austronesisch-Papoease**:161-163, see also **hh:hv:Cowan:Papuan**,
and can be verified with the subsequent SNT phonological reconstruction
**hh:hv:HartzlerGregerson:Proto-Tabla-Sentani** and the longer wordlists in
**hh:hw:SmitsVoorhoeve:Anceaux:B:I**.
Includes Abau, Yellow River, Iwam, Ram (Pouye, Karawa, Awtuw),
Wogumusin-Chenapian, Tama, Kwoma-Kwanga (Kwoma, Kwanga, Mende), Sepik Hill for
which the pronouns, gender markers as well as dative, locative marker and
benefactive verb are largely cognate **hh:hv:Foley:Sepik-Ramu**:126-139 and/or
there are significant lexical relations **hh:hvw:ConradDye:USepik**:12-14. The
Ndu languages do not show cognate pronouns or gender markers, and there is there
is a detailed refutation of the evidence so far presented that Ndu is related to
Kwoma-Kwanga (or the rest of Sepik) **hh:g:Aikhenvald:Manambu**. Yerakai shares
no significant lexical relations with any Sepik language
**hh:hvw:ConradDye:USepik**:14, except Ndu **hh:hv:Laycock:Sepik**:23, but these
are arguably loans from the adjacent Iatmul (as of intermarriage)
**hh:hvw:ConradDye:USepik**:14. No other argument for a Sepik affiliation in
offered **hh:hvld:LaycockZGraggen:Sepik-Ramu**:738 and Yerakai is not mentioned
in Foley's re-consideration of the Sepik family **hh:hv:Foley:Sepik-Ramu**.
Similarly, there is no evidence that Biksi is Sepik since nothing significant
was presented **hh:hvld:LaycockZGraggen:Sepik-Ramu** and the lexical evidence
does not warrant it **hh:hvw:ConradDye:USepik**. The Bikaru-Bragge wordlist in
**hh:hvw:ConradLewis:USepik** presumably represents the Pikaru dialect of
Bisorio (an Engan language) despite the divergence of the two, since the body
part terms agree and the elicitation sessions were monolingual.

endangerment.comment: Seri (5846-sei) = Threatened (80 percent certain, based on the evidence available)
Shabo (1379-sbf) = Severely Endangered (80 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

endangerment.comment: Shom Peng (5146-sii) = Threatened (60 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

classification.family: As Prost **hh:s:Prost:Seme**:345 noted, apart from obvious loanwords, Siamou is neither Mande nor Gur. Contra **hh:vw:Person:Siamou**, although there are typological matches, Simaou differs from Kru throughout the comparison, and Siamou can thus not be verified as a Kru language **hh:hv:Zogbo:Kru** **hh:v:Vogler:Siamou**. It lacks any of the diagnostic features of the Atlantic-Congo family and must thus be regarded as unrelated until such evidence is brought forward **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**.

endangerment.comment: Siamou (sif-sif) = 6a* (Vigorous).

classification.family: Hruso-Aka [hru] is clearly not a Miji dialect as held by **hh:hv:Shafer:Hruso**. The shared lexicon is attributable to loans, and of what remains, there are insufficient Tibeto-Burman parallels for a Tibeto-Burman affiliation **hh:hv:Padun:NAssam**, **hh:hvw:BlenchPost:Arunachal** **hh:hv:Anderson:West-Kameng**, **hh:v:Anderson:Hruso**. The Kamengic group, Puroik, Miju, Mishmic and Koro-Milang show little Tibeto-Burman cognacy, but what they do show is slightly in favour of inheritance (rather than borrowing) since they occur in the basic vocabulary **hh:hv:LieberherrBodt:Kho-Bwa**, **hh:hvw:BlenchPost:Arunachal**, **hh:hv:Burling:NEIndia**, **hh:hv:PostBlench:Siangic** **hh:hv:Anderson:West-Kameng**, **hh:v:Anderson:Hruso** and in grammar in the case of Koro-Milang **hh:hv:Anderson:West-Kameng**.

endangerment.comment: Siuslaw (8390-sis) = Dormant

family: No obvious lexical or other significant links with Mek, Western Ok, Awyu-Dumut
or Bayono-Awbono.

classification.family: The Nilo-Saharan affiliation à la Ehret or Bender is thoroughly dismantled by Nicolaï, and the Berber-like lexical stratum remains inconclusive.

family: Evidence for inclusion in Trans New Guinea is weak
**hh:hvld:Voorhoeve:CWTNG**:437-446, especially lexically. The same can be said
for a relation with Inanwatan, Konda-Yahadian and the older West Papuan
affiliation **hh:hvtyp:BerryBerry:SBH**.

classification.family: (South) Omotic does not show diagnostic Afro-Asiatic features **hh:hv:Hayward:Omotic:2004**, **hh:hv:Bender:Omotic**, **hh:hv:Bender:Omotic:Lexicon**, **hh:hv:Theil:Omotic**, **hh:hv:Bender:Omotic:2010**, **hh:hvld:Yigezu:Aroid**, and is therefore excluded until such features can be shown. The Mao languages (Hozo, Seze, Bambeshi and Ganza) have not yet been shown to be (North or South) Omotic in morphology and/or core vocabulary, though there are some resemblances with North Omotic **hh:hv:Bender:Mao**, **hh:hv:Bender:Gumuz-Koman-Mao-Omotic**, **hh:hv:Bender:Omotic**, **hh:hv:Bender:Omotic:1975**, **hh:hv:Bender:Omotic:2010**. The evidence for the coherence of North and South Omotic (= Ari-Banna) **hh:hv:HaywardTsuge:Omotic**, **hh:hv:Fleming:Omotic-Cushitic:Lamberti**, **hh:hv:Lamberti:Ari-Banna:1961**, **hh:hv:FlemingLewis:Ari-Banna** is not sufficient **hh:hv:Fleming:Lamberti:Second**, **hh:hv:Lamberti:Ari-Banna**, **hh:hv:Zaborski:Afroasiatic:2007**, **hh:hv:Bender:Omotic:2010**, **hh:hvld:Yigezu:Aroid**.

family: Typological arguments are not sufficient to conclude a Leonard Schultze family
with Walio **hh:hvld:LaycockZGraggen:Sepik-Ramu**. Neither is the shared
animate-suffix with Walio conclusive of a genetic relation
**hh:hvw:ConradLewis:USepik**. The lexical evidence does not show any conclusive
genetic relationship either, be it inside or outside Leonard Schultze
**hh:hvw:ConradDye:USepik**, or with Papi **hh:hvw:ConradLewis:USepik** (a higher
figure (29%) of Papi-Duranmin lexicostatistical relations quoted by Laycock
earlier, is superseded by the later, below 10%, figures of Conrad and Lewis).

endangerment.comment: Asaba (2687-seo) = Threatened (60 percent certain, based on the evidence available)
Sulka (10810-sua) = Threatened (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

lexvo: ภาษาสุเมเรีย [th]

hh_ethnologue_comment.comment: Sumerian, an extinct ancient language isolate whose existence is well-known, but not found in E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:g:Edzard:Sumerian**).

endangerment.comment: Sumerian (sux-sux) = 10 (Extinct).

classification.family: No conclusive, methodologically sound basis for assigning Surmic to Eastern Sudanic **hh:hv:Bender:ESudanic** or to an alleged full or partial Nilo-Saharan has been presented **hh:hv:Blench:Nilo-Saharan**, **hh:hv:Bender:Nilo-Saharan:2000**, **hh:hv:Boyeldieu:Nilo-Sahariennes** **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:294-309. The parallels adduced by **hh:hv:Dimmendaal:Nilo-Saharan:Stable** have been selected from various modern languages and have an alternative explanation as chance resemblances until shown to be reconstructable in the various microgroups.

family: **hh:hv:Wurm:Trans-Fly**:325 claims that Waia is related to the Pahoturi languages
but adduces no evidence and there is certainly nothing obvious that links the
two. Pronouns were not explicitly examined (and perhaps not implicitly either)
by Ross **hh:hv:Ross:Pronouns** but, in any case, they do not match Pahoturi.

hhbib_lgcode: Hiwi in villages of Kaibenapi-Genapi-Wagami and Bobonapi-Wariadai and Sarau north of Damira on the Fly River judging from comparison with Reesink 1976
Tabepi village mentioned by Reesink 1976 there are exclusive matches but also very many different words nevertheless
Tapapi Villages of Ubaroniara and Bogabw close to and north of the source of the Sagero Creek which is a tributary of the Lower Fly
Villages of Hibaradai (or Irotonapi)-Mawadai (or Hauwara) and Eriga north of Damira on Fly River judging from comparison with Reesink 1976

endangerment.comment: Tabo (6674-knv) = Threatened (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

classification.family: Laycock's assignment to Sepik-Ramu was for mainly typological reasons **hh:hvld:LaycockZGraggen:Sepik-Ramu**:757 and cannot be said to constitute sufficient evidence for an affiliation to any Sepik-Ramu (sub-)family. See also **hh:gd:KulickTerrill:Tayap**:8-13 **hh:hv:Foley:Sepik:2013**

endangerment.comment: Taiap (2216-gpn) = Severely Endangered (60 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

family: Jiamao [jio] has recently been suggested as a language isolate with heavy Hlai
overlay **hh:hvwphon:Norquest:Proto-Hlai**. However, if the suggestion of
massive borrowing from Hlai into Jiamao is in fact correct, so little residual
vocabulary remains that it appears insufficient for positing a new language
isolate. Therefore Jiamao is counted as a Hlai, and thus Tai-Kadai, language.

hh_ethnologue_comment.comment: Takelma [tkm], a well-attested extinct language isolate, is missing from E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:g:Kendall:Takelma**, **hh:hvb:Golla:California**, **hh:gt:Sapir:Takelma**).

endangerment.comment: Takelma (tkm-tkm) = 10 (Extinct).

family: There are occasional lexical links to the Sechuran language
**hh:hv:Adelaar:Andes**:398-400, but the very limited data available is not
compelling towards a genetic relationship.

hh_ethnologue_comment.comment: Tallán, an extinct poorly attested Peruvian language of uncertain affiliation, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:w:Zevallos:Costa**, **hh:hv:Adelaar:Andes**, **hh:w:Ramos:Tallan**, **hh:hvw:Loukotka:Inconnues**).

endangerment.comment: Tallán (NOCODE_Tallan-NOCODE_Tallan) = 10 (Extinct).

classification.family: No conclusive, methodologically sound basis for assigning Tama to Eastern Sudanic **hh:hv:Bender:ESudanic** or to an alleged full or partial Nilo-Saharan has been presented **hh:hv:Blench:Nilo-Saharan**, **hh:hv:Bender:Nilo-Saharan:2000**, **hh:hv:Boyeldieu:Nilo-Sahariennes** **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:294-309. The parallels adduced by **hh:hv:Dimmendaal:Nilo-Saharan:Stable** have been selected from various modern languages and have an alternative explanation as chance resemblances until shown to be reconstructable in the various microgroups.

hh_ethnologue_comment.comment: Tambora, an extinct non-Austronesian language of Indonesia, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:h:Balbi:Atlas:I**, **hh:hvw:Donohue:Tambora**, **hh:h:Steinhauer:Austronesian**).

endangerment.comment: Tambora (xxt-xxt) = 10 (Extinct).

family: Links with Mairasic are unconvincing lexically and pronominally
**hh:hvld:Voorhoeve:CWTNG**:424-431.

endangerment.comment: Tanahmerah (10732-tcm) = Endangered (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

family: Despite **hh:hvw:Evans:Minkin**, the lexical evidence for a relation to Minkin
shows no regular correspondences, and the case does not improve when considering
proto-Tangkic rather than the modern Tangkic languages (p.c. Erich Round 2013).

endangerment.comment: Taruma (6969-tdm) = Critically Endangered (80 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

hhbib_lgcode: La lengua Pinche matriz de las lenguas Roamaina/Uspa/Arazá

endangerment.comment: Taushiro (2163-trr) = Critically Endangered (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

family: The suggested Pawaian relation is based on lexicostatistics and typological
features **hh:hvld:MacDonald:Teberan**, while e.g. the pronouns do not match
systematically **hh:hvld:Wurm:ECTNG**:501-504.

classification.family: No conclusive, methodologically sound basis for assigning Temeinic to Eastern Sudanic **hh:hv:Bender:ESudanic** or to an alleged full or partial Nilo-Saharan has been presented **hh:hv:Blench:Nilo-Saharan**, **hh:hv:Bender:Nilo-Saharan:2000**, **hh:hv:Boyeldieu:Nilo-Sahariennes** **hh:hv:Guldemann:Africa:Classification**:294-309. The parallels adduced by **hh:hv:Dimmendaal:Nilo-Saharan:Stable** have been selected from various modern languages and have an alternative explanation as chance resemblances until shown to be reconstructable in the various microgroups.

hh_ethnologue_comment.comment: Timote-Cuica, an extinct isolated language of present-day Venezuela, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:s:Rivet:Timote**, **hh:phon:Arrieta:Timote**, **hh:w:Lares:Venezolanos**, **hh:s:Arrieta:Timote**).

endangerment.comment: Timote-Cuica (NOCODE_Timote-Cuica-NOCODE_Timote-Cuica) = 10 (Extinct).

family: The lexical and pronominal evidence for a Trans New Guinea affiliation is much
too weak **hh:hv:Pawley:TNG**:683, **hh:hv:Holtonetal:Alor**, cf.
**hh:hv:Pawley:Chequered-TNG**:94-95. The newest comparison of cognates
**hh:g:Kratochvil:Abui**:6-11 cannot muster a strong case (correspondences are
few, weak and not systematic enough). Likewise, the Bomberai/Alor comparisons in
**hh:hv:Hull:Timor** are flimsy.

hh_ethnologue_comment.comment: Timucua, an extinct language isolate of Florida, is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:g:AdamVinson:Timvqvana**, **hh:h:Goddard:Small-Western-Southeast**).

endangerment.comment: Timucua (tjm-tjm) = 10 (Extinct).

hhbib_lgcode: Pamiguas (Affiliated with Tinigua according to Ortiz 1965 etc)

endangerment.comment: Tinigua (2146-tit) = Critically Endangered (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)
Tiwi (2574-tiw) = Threatened (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)
Tonkawa (tqw-tqw) = 9 (Dormant). Language of registered tribe: Tonkawa Tribe of Indians of Oklahoma.

family: The pronouns for Tor are not Trans New Guinea and other arguments have not been
offered **hh:hvld:Voorhoeve:CWTNG**:413-414, nor are there any apparent
relations in newer data published after Voorhoeve. Tor and Orya are
unquestionably related **hh:phon:Fields:Orya**,
**hh:hw:SmitsVoorhoeve:Anceaux:B:I**.

endangerment.comment: Touo (10811-tqu) = Threatened (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)
Trumai (2132-tpy) = Critically Endangered (80 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

classification.family: See **hh:hv:Vovin:Altaic** **hh:v:Georg:Paradigmatic-Morphology** for the latest critique of Altaic.

endangerment.comment: Tunica (8969-tun) = Awakening

family: There is parallel in relational prefix with Carib and (Macro-Je) which is
suggestive but not conclusive **hh:hv:Rodrigues:Tupi-Karib-Je**

classification.family: See **hh:hv:Vovin:Altaic** **hh:v:Georg:Paradigmatic-Morphology** for critique on the Altaic hypothesis.

endangerment.comment: Tuxá (tud-tud) = 9 (Dormant).

family: Dixon's suggestion **hh:h:Dixon:Australian2002** received a shattering review by
Evans **hh:hv:Evans:Australia**. It has been suggested that Ngurmbur and
Bugurnidja were dialects of, or related to, Umbugarla
**hh:g:Harvey:Gaagudju**:14 but no data for these are actually attested (p.c.
Nicholas Evans and Mark Harvey 2013).

Afra (2799-ulf) = Threatened (60 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

**hh:s:Maccioni:Lule**:li-lv.

which has another sub dialect called Batyamal

endangerment.comment: Batjamalh (3360-wdj) = Severely Endangered (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

family: So far there has been no published case for a relation with Yangmanic beyond
typological similarities and very low cognate percentages
**hh:s:Wilson:Wagiman**:5-6, and there is no obvious relation between the two
**hh:g:Cook:Wagiman**.

endangerment.comment: Wagiman (2576-waq) = Severely Endangered (40 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

family: Typological arguments are not sufficient to conclude a Leonard Schultze family
with Papi **hh:hvld:LaycockZGraggen:Sepik-Ramu**. The lexical evidence does not
show any conclusive genetic relationship either, be it inside or outside Leonard
Schultze **hh:hvw:ConradDye:USepik**, **hh:hvw:ConradLewis:USepik**.

endangerment.comment: Waorani (2065-auc) = Threatened (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)
Warao (1953-wba) = Vulnerable (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)
Washo (1149-was) = Severely Endangered (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

family: The inclusion of the poorly known Karas is best argued in
**hh:hvw:Cowan:Ambtelijk**:33-36, with systematic correspondences in pronominals
and a few items of basic vocabulary. Evidence for inclusion in Trans New Guinea
is weak **hh:hvld:Voorhoeve:CWTNG**:432-437, both lexically and pronominally,
cf. **hh:hv:Pawley:Chequered-TNG**:94-95. Likewise, the East Timor/Alor
comparisons in **hh:hv:Hull:Timor** are flimsy.
There are interesting parallels to Plateau Penutian (= Klamath-Modoc, Sahaptian
and Molala) **hh:hv:Liedtke:WintuanPenutian**.
Wiru shares some cultural vocabulary and some typological features with Engan
**hh:hv:Kerr:Wiru** but is otherwise very different **hh:hv:Franklin:Engan**. I
am indebted to Tim Usher for bringing to my attention how different Wiru
actually is from Engan.

endangerment.comment: Wiru (5177-wiu) = Vulnerable (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)
Xukurú (xoo-xoo) = 9 (Dormant).
Yalë (10682-nce) = Endangered (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)
Yagan (1647-yag) = Critically Endangered (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

hh_ethnologue_comment.comment: Yana, an extinct Californian language isolate is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 (**hh:hvb:Golla:California**, **hh:sd:SapirSwadesh:Yana**).

endangerment.comment: Yana (ynn-ynn) = 10 (Extinct).

family: So far there has been no published case for a relation with Wagiman beyond
typological similarities and very low cognate percentages
**hh:s:Wilson:Wagiman**:5-6, and there is no obvious relation between the two
**hh:g:Cook:Wagiman**.

classification.family: Evidence for Trans New Guinea membership **hh:hv:Dutton:SETNG**:624-631 **hh:hvld:McElhanonVoorhoeve:TNG** or with other neighbouring families **hh:hv:Dutton:SETNG**:624-631 is clearly insufficient, as the lexical links so far proposed are few and show irregular one-consonant correspondences.

endangerment.comment: Yele (10812-yle) = Threatened (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

classification.family: The link to Eyak-Athapascan-Tlingit **hh:hv:Vajda:Dene-Yeniseian** is not yet mature enough to conclude a genetic relationship **hh:hv:Campbell:Dene-Yeniseian** **hh:hv:Starostin:Dene-Yeniseian** **hh:hv:Gerber:Dene-Kusunda**, **hh:hv:Vajda:Dene-Yeniseian-Progress**.

family: Yerakai shares no significant lexical relations with any Sepik language
**hh:hvw:ConradDye:USepik**:14, except Ndu **hh:hv:Laycock:Sepik**:23, but these
are arguably loans from the adjacent Iatmul (as of intermarriage)
**hh:hvw:ConradDye:USepik**:14 **hh:hv:Aikhenvald:Sepik**. No other argument for
a Sepik affiliation in offered **hh:hvld:LaycockZGraggen:Sepik-Ramu**:738 and
Yerakai is not mentioned in Foley's re-consideration of the Sepik family
**hh:hv:Foley:Sepik-Ramu**.

endangerment.comment: Yerakai (10602-yra) = Endangered (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

family: Evidence for a Sepik affiliation is too scant, though data is very scant too. No
convincing lexical relationship with Kimki **hh:hwsoc:Kim:Yetfa**.

endangerment.comment: Yetfa-Biksi (10579-yet) = Threatened (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

family: The family is assumed on lexical similarities hinted at by Laycock. What little
data on Yuat that was available to Foley in connection with his demonstration of
the Lower Sepik-Ramu family, it was not sufficient for a genetic relationship
with Lower Sepik-Ramu. Sufficient argumentation for a relation with the
Mongol-Langam languages is wanting **hh:hv:Laycock:Sepik**.

endangerment.comment: Yuchi (1002-yuc) = Critically Endangered (80 percent certain, based on the evidence available)
Yuracaré (1634-yuz) = Threatened (20 percent certain, based on the evidence available)

family: There are some miscellaneous resemblances to language in the Nadahup family
